titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.49 Richmond, Va. Thursday, February 26, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter Cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: From Fredericksburg.
div3.p:
The heavy snow storm which began to fall Saturday night and continued all day Sunday has banished all possibility of Yankee movement in this direction, although they are still numerous on the Stafford side.
The drifted depths of ten or twelve inches at least give assurance of a plentitude of mud, that potent element in war, which will last for some time to come.
So much for our "situation," present and prospective.

"The roar of the sullen drum" and the sullen gun on Sunday morning excited our hopes and expectations that the Yankees were crossing, or that we had crossed.
Gun after gun echoed through the storm of wind and rain, and made the heart leap with delight at the now familiar sound — the tocsin of battle and the harbinger of victory.
At last we learned that the Yankees were desecrating the Sabbath and the memory of Washington by celebrating his birthday by the noise of war on the day consecrated to the Prince of Peace.
But, for the day I should have proposed that our boys should fire half a dozen shells into the Lacy House and then "retract" them; as the Yankees did those five balls they fired upon our train of women and children leaving Fredericksburg last November.

By the way, let me tell of an incident which has come to my cars, to show that Fredericksburg almost had her "Jackson," like Alexandria in the beginning of the war. A very determined citizen, when he found the Yankees were to occupy the town, put his wife and children, and the provisions he had collected for their support, in one room of his house, armed himself, and stood at the door.--Several Yankees essayed to enter, when he told them his wife and children were in that room, and his provisions, without which they must starve, and he had made up his mind that no man should enter it alive as long as he lived; and he would have kept his word.
A Yankee officer stopped up and told him he was right and forbade the men to molest him. Had the attempt been made, I am confident Fredericksburg would have had her Jackson.

The soldiers here are in fine health and spirits.
Barksdale's boys still "hold the town, " as they did on the 11th of December, when they drove the enemy back, and would have driven them across the bridge, or into the river, had not Gen. Lee ordered them to retire.

A good deal of inspection has been going on recently by that accomplished officer, Major Costin, of the Eastern Shore, who is on General McLaw's staff Passing up the street the other day I saw him inspecting Lieut. Col. Luce's 18th Mississippians, whom he complimented as "A No. 1" This regiment has been in service since April, 1861.--Its first Colonel, B. R. Burt, was killed at Leesburg, in October, 1861, where it first had an opportunity to distinguish itself.
It has done good service and hard fighting also at Manassas, Savage's Station, Malvern Hill, Sharpsburg, and Fredericksburg, besides in any number of skirmishes.
At Malvern Hill Col. Griffin was severely wounded in the right side, and has been kept at home ever since Lt.-Col. Luce has commanded them in his absence, and led them where danger was greatest and the fight was hottest.
I met him with Colonel (now General) Bar Udale, on James River, after the fight at Malvern Hill.
Col. B. told me then that during that terrible fight one of his Captains came up and said he had but two men left of his whole company.
On the 11th of Dec. the 18th was in Fredericksburg and at Deep Run, and they, with the other Mississippi and a Florida regiment, kept back the enemy until dark.
They have 697 left out of 1,008 men at first, having lost about 300 killed and wounded. At Leesburg they drove the enemy with the bayonet, and had 23 killed and 65 wounded. They lost Capt. B. T. Henry at Malvern Hill.
He was 65 or 70 years of age.

There is one Mississippian here who must be descended from Goliah, as he is upwards of seven feet high, and broad in proportion.
I hear there is one private in the ranks, who is a planter, worth $800,000, and many of them are among the wealthiest gentlemen of Mississippi.
I have mentioned the 18th regiment because I happened to become acquainted with its officers, whose deeds and endurance I regret I have not space to record.
If every regiment in our army could be "reported" occasionally, it would animate and emulate to maintain and deserve praise and reputation for which in fact every soldier fights.

Some of the boys get into mischief sometimes and burn other people's fences, &c, in cold weather.
General Barkedale, I am sure, would cheerfully arrest and remedy and prevent all . I heard of one offence it would be hard to A Mississippian took unto himself a wife among the fair daughters of Fredericksburg.
While the ceremony was going on, one of the uninvited outsiders put his ramrod through the window and abstracted the wedding cake, and when wanted it not found."

Balls and parties are frequent.
The Minstrels drew crowded houses last week.
The Barksdale Thespians gave their first performance last night.
It numbers among its members Professors Nutting Crouch, and others, distinguished musicians, who discoursed most eloquent Some pieces were exquisite. "Box and Cox" gave promise of being fine actors, and "brought down the house" very often, while Briley seemed a soldier "of infinite just.".

The Yankee news from Congress and Connecticut shows symptoms of civil war, if they were a logical race.
J. Van Buren was very peaceful until after the New York election.
Connecticut Democrats are pledged to resist laws which must be enforced before their election.
Will they do it?

div4.head: Another Plea for Peace — a Renegade Suing for Mercy.
div4.p:
Mr. Conway, a native of Maryland, but a member of the Federal Congress from Kansas, and one of the most ultra-abolition members, has made a strong speech in favor of peace and the stoppage of the war. The speech is said to have the approval of Gov. Andrew, Charles Sumner, Wendell Phillips, Horace Greeley, and other leading Abolitionists, who held a caucus in Washington just before it was delivered.
We take the following extracts from it, which show its character:

div4.head: Against re-union.
div4.p:
I am not in favor of restoring the constitutional relations of slaveholders to the Union, nor of the war to that end. On the contrary, I am utterly and forever opposed to both.
I am in favor of the Union as it exists to day. I am in favor of recognizing the loyal States as the American nation, based as they are on the principle of freedom for all, without distinction of race, color, or condition.
I believe it to be the manifest destiny of the American nation to ultimately control the American continent on this principle.
I conceive that, therefore, the true object of this war is to revolutionize the national Government by resolving the North into the nation and the South into a distinct public body, leaving us in a position to pursue the latter as a separate State.
I believe that the direction of war to any other end is a perversion of it, calculated to subvert the very object it was designed to effect.

I have never allowed myself to indulge in that superstitious idolatry of the Union so prevalent among the simple but honest people, nor that political can't about the Union so prevalent among dishonest ones.
I have simply regarded it as a form of government to be valued in proportion to its merits as an instrument of national prosperity and honor.

div4.head: The South independent.
div4.p:
The war which has come in between the North and the South for the past two years, has made a revolution.
It has substituted in the South another Government for that of the Union.
This is the fact and the fact in such a matter is the important thing.
It settles the law. No technicality in a question of this kind can stand.
The war has utterly dissolved the connection between the North and South, and rendered them separate and independent powers in the world.
This is the necessary legal effect of civil war anywhere.
It makes the belligerent parties independent for the time being, and unless the one succumbs to the other, they continue independent of each other forever.
The principle is laid down by Vattel as follows: When a nation becomes divided into two parties, absolutely independent, and no longer acknowledging a common superior, the State is dissolved, and the war between the two parties stands upon the same ground in every respect as a public war between two different nations.
Book chapter 17 page 428. It is not to be wondered at, therefore, that so learned and profound a jurist as the honorable member from Pennsylvania (Mr. Stevens) should express the same opinion. * * *

div4.head: The Democracy true to the Union.
div4.p:
The Democrats will not, of course, listen to separation for an instant.
Such a suggestion, in their eyes is a proposition to dissolve the Union--for which one ought to be hanged.
They expect the question whether the Union shall be restored by force or by compromise to be submitted to the people in the next election, and upon that to carry the country.
Their plan is to oppose the Administration simply on its anti slavery policy.
They put in issue the confiscation act, the Missouri emancipation act the President's proclamation of emancipation.
These measures they pronounce unconstitutional, deny the validity and everything done, or to be done, in pursuance of them.
In addition to this, they attack the Administration on account of its suspension of the writ of habeas corpus false imprisonments, corruption, imbecility, &c, and a thousand other incidents.
But on the war and the integrity of the Union they are like adamant itself.
They claim to favor the war for the sake of the Union, but to war. They say very truthfully that the Republicans have tried force for two years, and exhausted the country, and upon this claim the adoption of their method is all that is left to be done.
This is the manner in which the politicians of the country propose to terminate this great conflict.

div4.head: The great Conservative party.
div4.p:
An alliance seems recently to have been effected to this and between certain elements heretofore hostile.
The border State politicians are the remnant of the old Whig and Know Nothing party, who, all their lives, cherished an intense haired to the Democracy.
They now unite with that party to effect this object.
The Republicans of the Albany school, under the sagacious leadership of Mr. Weed, who for long years fought the Van Bureau regency, and finally broke it down through the agency of free soil, are also hand-in- glove with their old opponents.
Thus the army of the Democracy takes the field for the next great political battle, supported on the left by the followers of Clay and Crittenden, and on the right by the special friends of Wm. H. Seward.
Such a host may well feel confident.
It is a combination for victory.
The elements have been well-shaped.
Not in vain have the border State politicians through the hall of the Presidential mansion — Not in vain has the discreet Secretary of State incurred the reputation of having become imbecile.
Not in vain has the whole Administration suffered the odium of drafting with the tide for lack of a policy.
They could well afford to dispense with the applause of the radicals, while they silently directed that under-current which was to refer the gigantic questions with which they would not grapple to the decision of another Presidential election.
The conservatives will triumph.

The chief element in the accomplishment of this reactionary movement is the war which the Administration is conducting for the restoration of the Union.
The war is, indeed, the trump card of the Democracy — not war for conquest, but Mr. Lincoln's war for the restoration of the Union.--They have no fear it will serve the end of Abolition.
It has passed that stage.
Its results are now in their keeping.
All they wish is its prolongation.
In the first place, it holds the nation pledged to the principle that the Union is intact and the Constitution open to amendment through Southern votes.
In the next place, the responsibility of it, being the Republicans, it weakens them sadly in the elections.
And in the third place, it is to wear away and depress the slaveholders, and dispose them in favor of conciliation.
The war, in whatever aspect it may be presented, is an admirable instrument for them.
If it should happen to meet with unexpected success, and defeat the rebellion, the slaveholders will be brought back just in time to join them in the election.
If it should lag and accomplish no results, as now seems likely, this will inevitably insure them a triumph in the popular vote.
Their theory is — and it is a sound ore — the two forces — Abolition and Secession — now in deadly conflict, have only to be permitted to continue the fight long enough to wear each other out, and cause the political waters to subside to their former level.

div4.head: The army Conservative.
div4.p:
Nevertheless, without reference to the result of the war, I consider the chances of the Conservatives in the election far superior to that of the Administration.
Great reliance is placed by the latter on the vote of the soldier; but, in my opinion, this is delusive.
The soldiers will be affected in like manner with the rest of the people and, moreover, will be tired of military service, and anxious to return home.
They will be dissatisfied from a thousand causes, and desire a change.
The sufferings and indignation yet to be engendered by the unlimited issue of an irredeemable paper currency will of itself overwhelm the Administration party and sink it deeper than plummet ever sounded.
But the Democrats, in my judgment, safely calculated that they can take issue on any of the hundred necessary incidents of the war, and defeat their opponents by a large majority.

div4.head: The proclamation a failure.
div4.p:
Many suppose that the effect of the proclamation of emancipation will so thoroughly, speedily, and completely annihilate and extirpate slavery, that the slaveholders will have no longer a motive to act together.
This is an egregious mistake.--The proclamation will have no such effect.
It cannot have any such effect.
Its constitutionality is denied.
It is still unexecuted and its validity undetermined.
The whole subject is yet open to debate and final settlement.
The Judiciary Department is to render its decision upon its and, in the meantime, it is to be the controlling issue in a popular election for President.
This state of things will undoubtedly inspire the slaveholders with a more resolute purpose than ever.
Their effect will not, as heretofore, be to prevent the Abolitionists from freeing the slaves, as a distant and speculative proposition, but to rescue him from the grasp of the enemy already actually laid upon him. It will redouble their will and bring out every latent energy.

div4.head: Sumner his Magnus Apollo.
div4.p:
The Senator from Massachusetts, (Mr. Sumner) who has lately been re-elected to serve another term of six years in the body he has so long adorned, should, in this crisis, point us to the proper action.
His purely Northern character, his great abilities, his lofty aspirations, his sacrifices for freedom, the entire confidence of his State, so spontaneously bestowed upon him and that State the noblest in America — all single him out as one authorized and required to speak with a decisive voice on this great occasion.
There are also in this House gentlemen whose wards on this momentous theme the country will listen to with intense interest.
The honorable member from Pennsylvania, (Mr. Thad. Stevens,) one of the truly great men of America — full of learning and wisdom — tried by long years of arduous service in this cause, who has never faltered, and is now re-elected in his district by overwhelming numbers, stands foremost among those of whom the Nation will expect deliverance from the dangers which encompass it.--Let these men, and such as these, speak and tell the country what to do in this hour of peril.
Nevertheless, I cannot refrain from expressing my individual opinion that the true policy of the North is to terminate this war at once.
The longer it continues, the worse our situation becomes.
Let the two houses of Congress adopt the following resolutions:

Resolved, by the Senate and House of Representatives, &c., That the Executive be, and he is hereby requested to issue a general order to all commanders of forces in the several military departments of the United States to discontinue offensive operations against the enemy, and to act for the future entirely on the defensive.

Resolved, That the Executive be, and he is further requested to enter into negotiations with the authorities of the Confederate States with reference to a cessation of hostilities, based on the following propositions: 1st.
Recognition of the independence of the Confederate States. 2d.
A uniform system of duties upon imposts 3d.
Free trade between the two States.
4th.
Free navigation of the Mississippi River. 5th.
Mutual adoption of the Monroe doctrine.

div4.head: Can live together.
div4.p:
I entirely disagree with those who assert that it is impossible that the North and South could live peaceably side by side because there are no natural boundaries between the two, such as the Rocky Mountains or the Atlantic Ocean.
This is a bugbear with which we impose upon ourselves.
The people of the North and South can never become foreign nations to each other in the sense in which the French and English and Russians are. They are sprang from the same origin, speak the same language, possess a common literature, inherit similar politics and religious views, and inhabit regions closely connected by natural and artificialities.
They will therefore both be American.
The only great difference between them is of a social and political nature, namely, that which arises from the existence of African slavery in one, and the absence of it in the other.
This fact, however, offers no obstacle whatever to such a separation as is involved in independent political jurisdiction; on the contrary, it greatly facilitates it. Before the Federal Union was established all the States were independent, and associated under Articles of Confederation, in the nature of a treaty.
The arguments now adduced to show the impracticability of present reparation between the North and South go with equal force to prove the impossibility of what then actually existed and was accepted in the case of the thirteen original States of the Union.
The latter stood toward each other precisely as the North and South would stand should they stop the war and enter into a treaty.
It would simply be resolving the North and South into Confederate States resuming, as to them, the old basis of the Confederation.
This would be the whole of it. It is, therefore, a very simple operation.
I do not suggest this, however, on the idea that should it ever be adopted the separation it implies would be permanent.
I believe that it would insure an ultimate reunion on an anti-slavery basis.

I have confidence in the inherent vitality of Northern civilization.
I have no fear to set in competition with the South.
Let them proceed side by side in the race of empire, and we shall see which will triumph.

div4.head: How to meet Lincoln's negro army.
div4.p: On the 10th inst., in the House of Representatives of the Confederate Congress, Mr. Hodge, of Kentucky, obtained leave to introduce the following preamble and resolution:

Whereas, Information has reached this Congress of the passage by the Congress at Washington, D. C., of a bill for the enlistment of negroes, as soldiers, in the armies of the United States, which armies are to be engaged in the further invasion of the Confederate States of America; and, whereas, the Constitutions both of the Confederate States and the United States recognize Africans and their descendants as property; and, whereas, we cannot consent to any change in their political status and condition: Therefore.

Resolved, That the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into the expediency of bringing in a bill providing the proper forms for the disposition of all negroes or mulattoes who may be captured from the enemy, in such manner that those of them who are fugitives from their masters may be returned to their rightful owners, and those for whom no master can be found shall be sold into perpetual bondage, for the purpose of raising a fund to reimburse citizens of this Confederacy who have lost their slave property by reason of the interference there with of the enemy.
Mr. Hodge addressed the House in favor of his preposition, after which it was agreed to.

div4.head: Massachusetts of old.
div4.p:
On the 8th November, 1792, the General Assembly of Massachusetts was in session in Concord, in consequence of a contagious disease in the capital.
The Governor, (John Hancock,) in his message, protested against the Presidential Act of Congress in the following words:

I feel the importance of giving every constitutional support to the General Government; and I also am convinced that the existence and well being of that Government depends upon preventing a confusion of the authority of it with that of the States separately.
But that Government applies itself to the people of the U. States in their natural, individual capacity, and cannot exert any force upon, or by any means control the officers of the State Governments as such: Therefore, when an act of Congress urges compulsory words with regard to any act to be done by the Supreme Executive of this Commonwealth, I shall not feel myself obliged to obey them, because I am not, in my official capacity, amenable to that Government.

My duty as Governor will most certainly oblige me to see that proper and efficient certificates are made of the appointment of Electors of President and Vice President; and perhaps the mode suggested in the act above mentioned may be found to be the most proper.
If you gentlemen, have any mode to propose with respect to the conduct of this business, I shall pay every attention to it.

Gentlemen, I do not address you at this time from a disposition to regard the proceedings of the General Government with a jealous eye, nor do I suppose that Congress could intend that clause in their act as a compulsory provision; but I wish to prevent any measure to proceed through inattention, which may be drawn into precedents hereafter, to the injury of the people, or to give a constructive power where the Federal Constitution has not expressly given it.

div4.head: Inside View of the war in the West--curious Davelopments.
div4.p:
The following are private letters of Gen. McCook, captured by our troops on the battle-field at Perryville.
They afford a curious insight into private Yankee views of the war and the personal things that pertain to it. The writer, McCook's father, is evidently a venomous old blackguard, whose morals are about on a par with his spelling:

div5.p:
Yours dated 25th ult., at New Market, was forwarded to us at Cincinnati, where your mother and I had went to spend a few days, I left her in the care of the Strano family in Kenty, and I returned to my business in this city.
I would have stopped over the Sabeth in Dayton — but a Riot was momentarily expected, and as I thought prudence the better part of valour, I did not Skedaddle, but I kept on in the train.

You no doubt see by the papers that the question, whether Buell, was at felt at the battle of Perrysville or not is still under discussion — let Mr. Buell and his friends say what they please, and let the Louisville Journal continue in his defence as long as Father Prentis, is able to wield a pen, there is but one prevailing opinion in the month of every intelligent man, and woman, that is, that he was willfully, and wickedly, guilty of a great misdemeanor, for which if he was put before a Jury of his countrymen, he would be condemned and shot, as the mildest possible mode of punishment--Thousands believe him to be a traitor, and that he desired your troops either to be out to pieces or captured — altho, I think he is largely interested in the welfare of the South, and would have no objection to see the Southern Confederacy perminently established, I do not think that he is a Traitor, and would sell his country — but his conduct in refusing to furnish you with the necessary support in your great extremity is most marvellous indeed.
And a great and wonton neglect that he can never explain away — And that infamous Gilbert is more worthy of death than the Coward Col. Taylor, who was very unwisely permitted to resign.

We have great cause of thankfulness to Almighty God, for the preservation of your life, and that your little division of raw troops had not been entirely destroyed and taken prisoners — when if Buell had advanced when you made your personal visete to him, he would have obtained a decided victory, and his temples now would have been adorned with a wreath of honor and glory, instead of the one of disgrace that now surround them.

I think that Bragg is not sustained by his Government in that inglorious retreat of his, altho the boast of capturing all the baggage and servants of Genl. McCook, he was not included in the batch of Lieut. Generals made since the battle while others much distinguished Men have been — this is significant of something — Mother, on parting with her, desired me to say to you, that she regretted deeply that she give her concent to let John go into the service.
She hopes that you will be able to induce him to return, and again enter College — and as he has seen the Elephant in a small way, and is yet sound in limb, perhaps he had better return, but as I had nothing to do with his entering I shall not interpose an opinion as to his return.

The command of a brigade may be taken from Daniel at any moment, when he would be compelled to join his regiment, or come home and resign.
Gen. McPherson, of the Army of the Tennessee, is anxious that he should take a position on his staff, but so long as Daniel remains in command of a brigade I would prefer that if he remains in the service that he remains where he is.

You will winter in Southern Tennessee or Northern Alabama, or Georgia.
If you do, I hope you will make the country bleed — remember the death of your lamented brother — we would all rejoice to see you in Ohio, enjoying the society of dear friends, and the many thousands of your admirers not only in but out of the State, but you cannot leave your command, until circumstances will justify it.

We had a letter from Edwin, since the battle of Corinth, his troops got there in time to be placed in advance after the retreating rebels and followed them to Tuscumbia river — they are both well and at Jackson, Tenn. You will soon see Gen. Rosecranse he can speak to you about Edwin, he treated him kindly at Corinth, he invited him to dine with him, which he respectfully declined.

I found Villard in Cincinnati, on his way to New York, let his feelings be what they may heretofore, he now sustains you, but is most bitter against Genl. Buell, Mother & I called on Col. Bomford at the residence of Mr. Hosea, Mother thinks he is not much of a Col. his Father was a good man.

Genl. Little speaks in the most condemnable manner of Buell, Judge Swain, of this City, came home with me last evening, he says if half what Little says about Buell, is true, that he ought to be hung — Villard fears a conspiracy between Buell, Crittenden, and Rousseau, to injure you, I cannot think that Rousseau would be guilty of a mean act towards you. I do not know whether his asking that his troops should be withdrawn from you command could be construed into opposition to you or not.--they are Kentuckyings and will bear watching — but I think Rousseau has said more about the immortal negro than you ever did.

We have heard nothing from Julia, since she left Louisville except from your letter, I think she had better return to Columbus, but I presume she thinks mother too much of an old fogy for her to associate with — again Mother is too great an economist further to live with.

Our best love to Daniel, John, Campbell, Hobletzell, the little yankee, Davis Baldwin and all enquiring friends.
Write as often as possible my love to Anson & Edward if in your command.
div5.closer:
Yours Affectionately
(Signed) Daniel McCook.
Major Gen. A. McD. McCook Someplace in Kenty or Tenn.
A true Copy. A. A. General.

div5.p: We have just learned from agent of the Governor that you are unwell — I presume that it arises from excitement and exposure from the battle of Perrysville — I hope you will soon recover with care and rest — Mother and I went to Louisville to see Daniel, we brought him home with us to this city — be had a pleasant time of it amongst your friends, they dined and supped him all his constitution would bear — he has returned to Louisville, and will to his command in a few days — if he would keep his quarters in a house he would get along well enough I presume you have seen the article by Villard, in the New York Tribune, of the 12th, Is you have not got it, I will send you Coppy--it is a scathing rebuke to Gen. Buell--a correspondent in the Cincinnati Commercial, of yesterday, tries to bolster him up in his general administrative conduct as an officer, and tries to relieve him by throwing a large amount of censure upon other gentlemen for not carrying out his suggestion in regard to the campaign in Kenty & Tenn, he passes over the battle of Perryville very smoothly, and never attempts to answer the general charges of incompetency and neglect which are made against him, I know very little about the capability of Committee appointed to investigate the charges, I Schroff, I presume is the ablest man on the board old man Tyler is an imbicile --Lew Wallace will not be disposed to probe very deep, as he thinks that he is at present under the bane of Genl Hallook, & others at, Washington, so that a vigor one investigation will depend entirely upon the legal talent of Don. H. Platt, if Joe Holt, was there as Judge Advocate you might expect an honest investigation, and full report but as it is, I think he well get a good white washing and let him slide — I am of the opinion that Buell ought to be dismissed the service, and that Gilbert, ought to hung, he and Buell I have no doubt understood each other, and wicked at your partial defeat on that bloody day — Gilbert being on trial Schroffe's testimony alone would convict him.

Martha was confined on the 18th inst, she has a fine Daughter weighing between 11 & 12 pounds at birth — we had a letter dated 21st instant, from Duport to day, the Mother and Daughter, were both doing well at that date.

We had a newspaper from Memphis the other day from the Dr, a note on the margin intimated that he was unwell, our Illinois troops from Jackson, must have separated at Grand Junction the 18th Regt to which the Dr. was attached going to Memphis and the 31st Edwins to Holly Springs — Hawia was well the last account we had of him — We have concluded to let John remain in the service until the opening of the next session in January when he will come home — Matters are not improving very fast on the Potomack since the displacement of McClelland Stonewall occupies Winchester with a large army, another Martinsburg, a third in Leesburgh nothing but a rise in the Potimack will prevent another raid into Maryland and Penns our army is trying to get South of the Rebels with the object of attacking Richmond infront, they are occupying the old Bull run battle field and may any day turn a column towards Washington, if they do, McClelland will be recalled and we may have a Military Dictator in Washington before the month of April next.

You will remember me to those of your staff that I am acquainted with, and to Col. Parrett, Dr. or Col. McMillan and his Rogt are exchanged, and are now reorganizing and is anxious to be assigned if possible to your command he is desirous to wipe out the stain received at Richmond — Mother sends kind regards and say take care of yourself.

closer.signed: Gen Alez McD. McCook remember me to Governor Andy Johnson & Maynard if in Nashville.
Nashville remember me to Governor Andy Johnson & Maynard if in Nashville.
Tenn. remember me to Governor Andy Johnson & Maynard if in Nashville.

div5.p:
In the Cincinnati Gazette of to-day I find the report of Gen. Buell's official report of his campaign in Kentucky, especially the battle of Perryville, in which, by his innuendoes, he tries to throw the defeat of our army in that battle at your door.
In your personal report on the morning of the 8th, I understand that you informed him that the enemy were in your front ready to attack you; did he then make arrangements to sustain you? --Even at the hour of 4 in the evening he hesitated to believe that the cannonading that he heard was nothing more than a reconnaissance.
What was his aids doing on the 8th, if he knew nothing that was going on in the vicinity?
I have no doubt that he will try, through his staff and other toddies, to throw the responsibility of that day upon you. I hope Rousseau will do you justice in denying the fact, that you brought on the engagement.
Be concedes the fact that the enemy had attacked Daniels Brigade, and that he was relieved between 10 and 11 o'clock by Buells orders, hence he must have known that the enemy were in the vicinity, and his entire forces ought ought to have been brought up, at least the Corps of Gilbert, that were within short range ought to have engaged the enemy — but they wanted to destroy you, and when he says the disaster is to be attributed to your great confidence in your self, that you could manage the matter without the knowledge or controls of you commander — does you great injustice.

I think Mitchell, Carlin, Sheriden, and Schreff will do you justice — let me hear from you after the commission leaves Nashville — and State whether he will attempt to throw the responsibilities of that sad day upon you — put Rousseau into the Mill make him shew his hand he will no doubt try and save Buell but he cannot charge that you were instrumental in bringing on the fight.

Mother has been in Washington for two weeks. She left for the west on Saturday, Martha and her Daughter are both doing well — the child is fine large healthy, and promises to be tolerably fair to look at — I understand that she is now in Pittsgle on her way to the West she will stop a short period in Steubenville, and may go out to Carrolton for a few days — George is in Washington, do not know what his business is.
Major, Arison went through this city on his way to Steubenvill, he has not yet returned.

Daniel I presume has joined his Regt ere this, we have not heard from him since he left this city.
Write soon.
div5.closer:
Affectionately Yours.
(Signed) Daniel McCOOK.
Alexander--Nashville, Tenn.
Edwin thinks that a friendly letter from you Gen McPherson would be of great service to him, if you have time write him a note.
Alexander. (Signed) Daniel.
A true copy — A. A. General

div4.p: --The Lieut. Governor, Mr. Montague, having returned, resumed his seat, and called the Senate to order at noon. Prayer by Rev. Mr. Molley, of the Methodist Church.
A number of bills were reported back from Committees, with and without amendments, and advanced to a second and third reading.

Mr. Johnson introduced a series of joint resolutions in relation to the preparation of a statistical estimate of the probable growth of cereals and all other kinds of food in Virginia the coming season, and instructing the Executive to forward a copy of the said resolutions to the Governors of each of the Confederate States, seeking their co-operation.--Read and laid over under the rules.

Resolutions of Expediency.--By Mr. Robertson: Inquiring into the propriety of increasing the wages of the members of the General Assembly, to take effect from the 30th day of June next.
By Mr. Lynch: Fixing the time of the meeting of the Senate at 11 A. M., instead of 12 M., after Monday next.
By Mr. Johnson: Inquiring into the expediency of allowing the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad company to increase its capital stock.
The resolutions were severally agreed to.

Disposition of Bills.--The bill to secure representation in the General Assembly from districts held by the power of the public enemy was tabled.
The bill to authorize fiduciaries to invest in Confederate bonds was discussed, amended, laid on the table, and made the order of the day for Thursday, at 11 o'clock.
A number of bills were advanced to a third reading and their engrossment.
Bills Passed--House bill for the improvement of the North Fork of the Holston river, in Smythe county; a bill for the relief of Zacharish L. Finney, of Pittsylvania.
Committee Bills Reported.--A bill to authorize the use of the jails of the State by the Confederate States; a bill to amend the act to increase jailors' fees.
At 3 o'clock, on motion, adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 11 o'clock.
Mr. Robertson submitted a resolution, which was agreed to, inquiring into the expediency of incorporating the Stonewall Water Power and Manufacturing Company.

On motion of Mr. Bouldin, the unfinished business of yesterday — the substitute for Senate bill empowering the Governor to call cut male slaves to work on fortifications, etc., was taken up, discussed, and amended until 2½ o'clock, when the substitute was adopted, and the bill read a third time and passed.

[The previsions of this bill make it the duty of the Governor, when called on by the President of the Confederate States so to do, to call into the service of the Confederate States to labor on fortifications and other works for public defence in this State, from time to time, for a period not exceeding sixty days, a number of male slaves, between the ages of 18 and 55 years, not exceeding at any one time 10,000 and not exceeding in any county, city, or town, five per centum of the entire slave population thereof — the requisition to be ratably apportioned among all the slaveholders in the sections called upon, so as to charge each with a certain proportion of his male slaves between the ages specified.
For all such slaves called out under this act the Confederate Government is required to pay to the owners thereof $20 per month and furnish the slave with soldiers' rations, medicines, and medical attention; and the value of all such slaves as may escape from the authorities so as not to be returned to their owner, or who may be killed or captured by the public enemy, or who shall die during their term of service, or thereafter from disease contracted while in such service, is to be paid for by the Confederate authorities.
As soon as the Governor has determined to make a requisition under this act, he shall lend to the Clerks of the several counties or corporations upon which the call is made couples of the requisition, and thereupon it shall be the duty of the Clerks to summons all the Justices to attend upon a day not later than six days from the filling of the requisition, who shall proceed to make the apportionment — not less than five members being present — ratably among all the slaveholders; but in no case of a soldier in the service, or of a widow having a son therein, or whose husband has died in such service, owning or hiring but one slave, such slave shall not be subject to the requisition; and no slaveholder, either as owner or hirer, shall be required to furnish any slave, unless he has in his possession one or more within the prescribed ages.
The apportionment having been made, the negroes are to be delivered through a Sheriff or Sergeant to an officer of the Confederate Government; and a failure to do so, unless upon good cause shown, the slave may be held for ninety days. In case of the failure or refusal of the Courts to perform the duties assigned them, the Clerk is required to at once notify the Governor, who shall, by officers of his own selection, with the aid of the Commissioners of the Revenue, impress the proportion of negroes therefrom as may not have been furnished under the provisions of this act; the slaves so impressed to be in all cases treated as those voluntarily furnished.
Receipts are to be given for all slaves seized or taken possession of under this act, and fines and penalties imposed upon those who fail to comply.
In making the requisition the Governor is required to equalize the burdens as nearly as may be among the several counties of the Commonwealth, with due regard to the number of slaves previously furnished.
In any county upon which a requisition is made it shall be lawful for any number of persons required to furnish not less than thirty nor more than forty slaves, to place such slaves in charge of an agent or overseer selected by such owners, who, if he be a fit person, shall be employed by the Confederate Government to take charge of the negroes aforesaid for the period of sixty days; and in any county, city, or town, in which the number of slaves amounts to twenty, and is less than thirty, an overseer or manager may be selected as aforesaid.--Owners may furnish subsistence or provisions for their slaves, and shall receive therefore commutation in money, in lieu thereof, equal to the commutation allowed to soldiers in the service.
Any request from the President of the Confederate States to the Governor for slaves, under the provisions of this act, to be regarded an assent to and acceptance of all its provisions by the Confederate Government.
The act to be in force from its passage)
Mr. Worsham offered a resolution, which was agreed to, instructing the Special Committee on Salt to inquire into the causes which have delayed the supply of salt ordered by Dinwiddle county Court.
Mr. Digger submitted a resolution, instructing the Committee on Propositions and Grievaness to inquire into the expediency of incorporating the Virginia Glee Club for the promotion of the fine arts.

On motion of Mr. Buford, the bill establishing a tobacco inspection in the town of Danville was read a second and third time, and passed.
Mr. Barbour moved that the tax bill be taken up Agreed to.
Mr. Barbour then moved that during the further consideration of the tax bill no member be allowed to speak more than once on any question, nor longer than ten minutes. Agreed to.
On motion, the House adjourned.
--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock M. by Mr. Hunter, of Virginia, and opened with prayer by Rev. T. V. Moore, of the Presbyterian Church.
Mr. Wigfall submitted the following resolution, which was agreed to:

Resolved, That a committee of three be appointed to inquire into the rights and duties of reporters admitted to seats upon the floor of the Senate; and also to inquire whether there has been any breach of those duties in certain comments recently made by a reporter in the columns of a newspaper published in this city on one of the members of this body.
[Committee — Wigfall, Yancey, and Johnson, of Arkansas]

The Senate were notified that the House had passed a bill for the equalization, &c., of the grade of officers of the Navy of the Confederate States, and for other purposes.
Also, that the President had signed an act to provide for refunding to the State of Alabama the amount overpaid by her on account of the war tax of 862.

The bill defining who shall be exempt from military service in the armies of the Confederate States was amended by inserting after the word "officers" in 21st line, 1st section, the words "other than the Judges of the Supreme, Distriot, Superior, Circuit, and Probate Courts, the Chancellors of State Courts, and Sheriffs, excluding Justices of the Peace," and passed.
Ayes 19, noes 4.

Mr. Brown, of Miss., introduced a bill to establish a volunteer Navy.
Referred to the Naval Committee.

Also, a bill to amend an act entitled "an act to authorize the Secretary of the Navy to make certain contracts without advertising for proposals," approved August 29, 1861; which was placed on the calendar.

Also, a bill authorizing the appointment of a Register, and an additional Clerk and Draughtsman for the Navy Department.
The bill and an amendment were ordered to be printed.
The bill amending the law in relation to Assistant Treasurers and Depositories was passed.

The bill fixing the rank of officers in the military and naval service of the Confederate States, holding commissions under the Provisional Government, when reappointed to offices of the same grade under the permanent Government, was transferred to the secret legislative calendar, and the Senate went into secret session to consider the same.

The doors being opened, House bill for the establishment and equalization of the grade of officers of the Navy of the Confederate States and for other purposes, was referred to the Committee on Naval Affairs.

The Message of the President of the Confederate States relative to slaves held by alien enemies in the Washington and New Orleans Telegraph Company, was referred to the Committee on Post-Offices and Post-Roads.
On motion of Mr. Hill, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Bishop Early of the M. E. Church.

Printing.--Mr. Barksdale, of Miss., from the Committee on Printing, reported back a resolution to print 5,000 copies of the Journals of the Convention which framed the provisional and permanent Constitutions and that of the Provisional Congress, with an amendment substituting 2,500 for 5,000--Passed — yeas 54, nays 25.

Bills Introduced.--Mr. Kenner, of La., from the Committee on Ways and Means reported a bill to lay taxes for the common defence and to carry on the Government of the Confederate States.
Made the order of the day for Monday next and ordered to be printed.

Mr. Chamblies, of Va., introduced a bill to amend an act to perpetuate testimony in cases of slaves abducted or harbored by the enemy, or of other property seized, wasted, or destroyed by them.--Referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

The Arrest of Soldiers.--The House resumed the consideration of unfinished business, viz: A bill reported from the Committee on Military Affairs, by Mr. Miles, to provide for the arrest of soldiers absent from their commands without leave, and providing compensation to their captors.
After some debate, in which Mr. Smith, of Va., Mr. Holt, and others, participated, the bill was laid upon the table on motion of Mr. Holt--yeas 51, nays 31.
On motion of Mr. Kenner, the House went into secret session.

div3.head: Recovery of stolen goods.
div3.p:
--A considerable quantity of the goods stolen from the dry goods establishment of Messrs. Chiles & Chenery seem likely to be recovered through the energy of the police.
Yesterday evening Myer Myers and Catharine Issacs, who reside in the large brick tenement on the south side of Main street, at the corner of 20th, were arrested and lodged in the cage, to await an examination before the Mayor on the charge of having in their possession a large quantity of dry goods, valued at $6,000, knowing the same to have been stolen from Chiles & Chenery.
The goods were identified by one of the firm by a private mark.
There were not, it is said, wanting other evidence of their ownership.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--Fifty-seven men were lodged in Castle Thunder yesterday morning.
Among the number were four conscripts from Lynchburg.--The balance were charged with desertion.
J. H. Grant, of company B, 27th N. C. regiment, died in the Prison Hospital yesterday.
The deaths there average one a day, owing to the bad condition in which many are who are received in the prison, where the exposure and want of many little comforts soon begets sickness.
Lieut George, W. M. Brown, and John Thomas, charged with assaulting and shooting at a man on Main street, were yesterday turned over to the Mayor by order of Major Griswold.

div3.head: Hustings Court, Wednesday, February 25th.
div3.p:
--Hon. W. H. Lyons presiding.--Wm. Lee, was put on trial for assaulting Lazarus Lawson a soldier, on 17th street, a few months since at night, and robbing him of a comb and empty pocket-book.
The jury, on hearing the evidence, retired, and regarding more the fellow's intent than the amount realized by the robbery, sent him to the State's prison for six years.

A. Mason, the person who personated an officer of the 6th Louisiana regiment, and received a bogus substitute into a bogus company, thereby defrauding Wm. M. Allen, of this city, of $1,200, which, through Mason's agency, he gave the party pretending to be a substitute was put on trial, and the jury, after hearing the evidence, sent him to the Penitentiary for four years. His accomplice, Rogers, escaped from the city jail.
Defendant is yet to be tried on a similar charge for swindling Wm. A. Charters of $1,200.

Thomas Turpin, a lad was put on trial for stealing $35 from David Smith near the Old Market. --The evidence was being heard at 6 o'clock last evening, and the trial was not expected to conclude that night.

div3.head: Mayor's Court, February 25.
div3.p:
--The case of Mary Connors, mother Mary Connors, her daughter, and Frances Hueston, for the alleged receiving of a portion of the dry goods recently stolen from the store of Chiles & Chenery, on Broad street, knowing the same to have been stolen, was party heard, and continued till the 27th lost.
It appeared from the testimony that about $200 worth of the stolen property was found in the house occupied by the above parties.
Jupiter, slave of Stephen Hunter, arrested for having no pass and obtruding himself on the lot of Mills Godwin without that gentleman's consent, was ordered ten lashes.
J. H. Ellison, arrested for getting drunk and behaving disorderly at the theatre, was admonished and discharged.
Robert, slave of Geo. M. Valentine, arrested for trespassing on Dr. C. B. Gibson's lot, was committed as a runaway.

Owen Smiley, arrested for being concerned in keeping a disorderly house on Broad street, and for violently assaulting officer Kelley, of the Day Police, and James Jones, of the 5th Texas reg't, was committed in default of $500 for his good behavior, and remanded, in two cases, to await indictment by the Grand Jury.
Aaron Kelley, charged with drunkenness and disorderly conduct in the street, was reprimanded and let off.
The case of Martha, slave of Mr. J. T. Vaughan, charged with attempting to poison her master's infant child, was partly heard and continued until the 26th inst.

div3.head: The Confederate Hospitals.
div3.p:
--In pursuance of the orders of the Surgeon General, the Confederate Hospitals located within the city limits are being rapidly vacated.
Some will be given up for good while the others will be vacated temporarily, the latter during the time undergoing a thorough cleansing, which they now much need.
In this connection we may remark that the health of our army was never better.

div3.head: Melting.
div3.p:
--The recent heavy deposit does not bid fair to encumber the ground very long in this vicinity.
Yesterday it was melting rapidly, the gutters giving evidence of the power of the sun. Several narrow escapes were made from masses of snow falling from the house tops with the power of a miniature avalanche on the sidewalks, which were hardly ever less crowded than on the occasion.
Several heavy signs on Main street were brought down by the melting snow.
We heard of no one being hurt.

div3.head: Solitary and Aliens.
div3.p:
--Only one Abolition prisoner was brought to Richmond yesterday.
He gave the name of J. Q. Phillips, private in Company D. 5th Pennsylvania Cavalry.
He was taken in custody on Tuesday, at Berryville, in New Kent county.

div3.head: Run over by a wagon.
div3.p:
--Mr. Charles Damotte, a baker, was run over by a wagon, on Main street. Tuesday night, and badly injured internally.
It was done accidentally.
The Supreme Court of Appeals of Virginia and the Confederate District Court were in session yesterday, but nothing was done worthy of notice.

div3.head: From Vicksburg — the city Shelled by the Yankees--no harm done.
div3.p: --The correspondent of the Advertiser and Register writes from Vicksburg, February 13th, as follows:

q.p:
"The enemy erected batteries on the levee, in range of the city, and commenced shelling at 1 o'clock yesterday, one of our batteries near the depot.
Every shell came within the city, but no harm was done.
Our guns replied slowly, giving shot for shot.
From the position of their batteries that portion of the city fronting the river will be untirable.
The firing continued at regular intervals till night, and occasionally till morning.
At daylight all was quiet. "

div3.head: From Port Hudson — movements of the enemy in Louisiana.
div3.p: (via Mobile, 25th.)--A flag of truce boat arrived from Baton Rouge yesterday, bringing 320 exchanged prisoners, belonging principally to the 18th and 30th Louisiana Regiments.
The New Orleans papers contain nothing of importance.
There was a report of the killing of Butler by Bouligny in Washington city.

There are evidences of an early advance upon this point.
Several mortar boats have arrived at Baton Rouge, also reinforcements, and intelligence received through prisoners strengthens this belief.
Prisoners state that reinforcements me continually arriving at New Orleans, and confirm previous reports of demoralization in Banks's army.

div3.head: From Charleston.
div3.p:
--We have trustworthy information from Beaufort that the difficulty between the Yankee Generals Hunter and Foster, which resulted in the return of the latter to Washington, was a fisticuffs between the rival Generals, growing out of a dispute as to precedence.
The new programme of Hunter is now understood to be another expedition to cut the Charleston and Savannah Railroad at Fecataligo, and simultaneous naval operations against Generals Point and Costan's Bluff, preliminary to attacking Savannah.
The 1st of March is the day fixed for these movements.
The merchant steamer which went aground yesterday is now within the harbor.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of 86 acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep Run Turnpike, at Auction.
div3.p:
--As Administrator of John Ford, dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and James Shephard.
It contains 85 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms; Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 8 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico co. and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Ford who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 49, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed in an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia," and sealed with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: The North Carolina soldiers.
div3.p: One of the Northern newspaper correspondents, who professes to be booked up upon matters and things in the South, undertakes to assert that the gallant soldiers of North Carolina are suspected of being less loyal to the Southern cause than the soldiers of other Southern States, and to have some secret hankerings after the old Yankee Union.

This is only a Yankee libel.
Its motive is as manifest as its malice, and it can impose upon no one but the half knaves and half fools by whom it was invented.
It is part and parcel of an insidious scheme which the Yankees have long been laboring at, to sow the seeds of jealousy and distrust in the minds of a portion of our people, and to distract and divide by these acts those whom they cannot conquer by their arms.
They pay a sorry compliment to the intelligence of North Carolina when they expect to deceive them by such shallow artifices, and reflect still more grossly upon their magnanimity and patriotism.
We profess to be as well informed at least as any Yankee newspaper upon men and things in the South, and it is news to us that the soldiers of North Carolina, or of any other Southern State, are looked upon with distrust and jealousy by their Southern compatriots.
On the contrary, we have never heard but one voice, and that of unqualified and enthusiastic admiration, of the sacrifices and heroism which North Carolina has manifested in this war. From the field of Bothel to the battle of Fredericksburg the soldiers of North Carolina have stood in the front ranks, and reaped laurels as bright and imperishable as ever crowned human brows.
In saying this we give utterance to the unanimous opinion of their gallant brethren in arms, and of the wholes Southern community.
It would suit the base cunning of the Yankees to alienate North Carolina, if they could, by making her believe that she is not appreciated by other Southern States; but a sensible people cannot be imposed upon by such shallow trickery.
They will ask why North Carolina should be looked down upon; why she who has been surpassed by no other State in self-sacrifice and heroism, should be singled out as the object of distrust and contempt?
Knowing that she has never given reason for such disparagement and that there is no ground upon which it can be based, they will scout the idea, not only as a libel upon themselves, but upon their heroic comrades who, side by side, have mingled their blood with their own upon every battle-field of the Confederacy.
As for North Carolina, or any other Southern State, yearning after an alliance with there Yankees, who have committed every conceivable outrage upon her property and people, it is a simple absurdity.
It is a monstrous insult, added to the cruel wrongs which she has already suffered at their hands, to represent her as eager to kiss the hand of the despoilers and ravishers who have darkened her homes and defiled her soil.
The Yankees must be reduced to desperation when they resort to such expedients to sustain their sinking fortunes.
If they really doubt the loyalty of North Carolinians to the Southern cause let them observe their conduct upon the next battle-field.
They will then receive from the proper source the proper answer to their malignant libels.

div3.head: Wm. H. Seward.
div3.p:
The North is at last discovering that Wm. H. Seward is no statesman.
The N. Y. World proves that he has no claims to that title, none of the qualities which fit a man to guide the helm of Government in times like these.
This fact was evident long ago to every observing man out of the United States. Mr. Seward is a polished demagogue and nothing more.
If he had possessed the foresight and moral elevation of a great statesman, he would never have permitted Lincoln to begin this war, or, being begun, he would have appreciated the soundness of Gen. Scott's views in the first letter of that personage to the Government, setting forth that the conquest of the South would be a work of years, requiring immense armies, and that it would be better to let the "erring sisters depart in peace. " Instead of this, he was totally unable to understand the magnitude of the undertaking on which he had ventured, and deluded his silly dupes with constant predictions of ending the war in sixty and ninety days, till the false prophet became such a laughing stock through all Christendom that he finally seems to have become ashamed of himself and the oracle has become dumb.
His total disregard of truth, and of the common courtesies of diplomatic intercourse in his relations with foreign powers, has sunk him beneath the contempt of gentleman in every land.
A statesman!
What could not a statesman have accomplished with the means and resources at his command?
There is no pettifogger at the New York Tombs who could have mismanaged the affairs of Government, committed more blunders, and disgraced himself and his country more completely than Wm. H Seward.

div3.head: The Federal capital.
div3.p:
A Northern speaker, referring to the state of things at Washington, says that the capital of the United States seems to be taken possession of by a congregation of run-mad ultraists, free lovers, and fanatics of every description.
Judging from his description, and from the conduct of the Government, Washington seems to have been converted into a vast lunatic asylum.

If those whom the gods would destroy they first make mad, the ruin of that hopeless Government cannot be far distant.
Madness from the very first has been palpable in all their words and actions.
Of late they have not been able even to keep up the outside show of sanity.
Let the South preserve its calmness and its determination.
The career of the Bediamites is drawing to a close, and the day-dawn of Southern Independence is gilding the eastern sky.

div3.head: Meeting of stockholders.
div3.p:
--A meeting of the stockholders of the Roanoke Valley Railroad Company will be held in the town of Clarksville, on Thursday, the 19th day of March, 1863.
A full meeting is desirable, as important business will be brought to the attention of the stockholders.
div3.closer:
By order of the Board.
E. A. Williams, Sec'y. fe 14--2awtd

div4.p:
On the 5th inst, at Union station, by the Rev. Wm.
H Christian, Thos G Blunt, of the 15th Va. Regiment, to Miss Virginia P Homes, daughter of B J Homes.
Yesterday morning, the 25th inst. by Rev Dr. Burrows, Mr. William H Wade to Miss Sallie K, daughter of the late Melvin W Dunnavant, all of this city.

On Sunday night, 22d inst, at 10½ o'clock, in Jefferson, Powhatan county, Va, at his mother's residence, after a lingering illness, of consumption Mr. A C Tyler, son of Mary E and the late Henry Tyler, aged 30 years 5 months and 25 days, leaving a devoted mother and sister, and many friends to mourn their irretrievable loss.

Of the deceased it may be truly said that he was a kind, fond, and affectionate son and brother; in his friendship, guileless and sincere; in his enmity, open, candid, and honorable; and in his intercourse with his fellow men, courteous and kind.
But it is not the design of the writer to indulge in eulogy; that would be idle.
Eulogy of the deed is too often sophistical, and designed to solace the bereaved ones.
Would to God I could offer consolation to those hearts — once happy, now disconsolate.
But the idol of those hearts is gone, and consolation can come only from that Divine source who holds in His grasp "the late of man and the destinies of worlds." A Friend.

His friends and acquaintances and those of the family are invited to attend his funeral this (Thursday) morning, at 10 o'clock, from the packet office of Messrs Boyd, Edmond & Davenport, thence proceed to the City Burying-Ground. [*]
On yesterday morning, at 11½ o'clock, John Warring, the youngest son of Susan Frances and Barney Osterbind, aged one year and six months.

His funeral will take place from his father's residence, corner of Cary and 18th sts. at 2 ½ o'clock to-day.
The friends are invited to attend. *

At Forrest Hill, Dallas county, Ala, at the residence of her father, on Thursday, the 18th instant, of scarlet fever, Maria Theodosia, youngest daughter of Col Robt W and Sarah Hunter Smith, aged 2 years 5 months and 8 days. *
Of scarlet fever, on the morning of the 30th of January, 1863, at the residence of her grandfather, Hon J S Hunter, Mildred Dauncy, daughter of Colt Robt W and Mrs Sarah H Smith, aged four years. *

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, of consumption, on the 19th of February, 1863 Mrs. Mildred B. Powers, wife of Jas D. Powers, Esq., of Caroline, Va, aged thirty-five years.

It is seldom one is called upon to record the death of a lady who possessed, in such an eminent degree, so many beautiful and endearing traits of character.
She was gentle in her manners, lovely in her disposition, discreet, chaste, a keeper at home, good, obedient.
Truly death is no respecter of persons, but lays his cold hands upon all ranks, ages, and characters.
Though Mrs. Powers was not a member of the Church she did not die destitute of a hope of a blessed immortality.
She had been the meek and patient sufferer for several years, but in all her afflictions she did not complain or murmur.
Being perfectly rational to the last and sensible of her condition, she spoke of her departure with composure, praying incessantly that the Lord would remove her without a struggle.
That prayer was literally granted.
She passed away without a sigh — no weeping eye, no heaving heart, no aching head, no anxious breast, but all was hushed into the quietness of unconscious insensibility — leaving a husband, four children, and a numerous circle of relations to mourn their irreparable loss.
"But I would not have you to be ignorant, brethren, concerning them which are asleep, that ye sorrow not even as others which have no hope."

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --A reliable man, over 45 years of age and a citizen of the Confederate States, to whom a liberal bonus will be paid.--Apply to day, between the hours of 9 and 11 A M, at
div3.closer:
Zimmer's Confectionery,
Opposite Bodeker's Drug Store,
No. 17 Main street. fe 26--1t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For the war. For a reliable man, over 45 years of age, a fair price will be paid.
Address, immediately, "Box 139," Petersburg, Va. This is a fair chance for a man to make his own commissions without an agent.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To go into an infantry company in General Jackson's corps, now near Fredericksburg.
For a reliable man, over 45 years of age a liberal price will be paid.
Call on W S Wright, at Camp Lee for two days.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted immediately a substitute.
One well recommended can obtain a good price and the privilege of choosing his own company.
Apply at No. 111 Main street.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For one who can come well recommended a liberal price will be paid.
Apply early at R H Dibrell's, on Shockoe Slip

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman who has had long experience as a merchant and accountant, and who is at leisure after 3 o'clock P M, wishes to obtain employment during that portion of the day in Bookkeeping or any other kind of writing.
Satisfactory references can be given.
Address "Box 827," Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To buy a handsome set of Rosewood or Mahogany Chamber Furniture A good price will be paid for the same if application is made immediately.
No one need call unless it is handsome and modern.
Call at 98 Main street.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Two good Bread and Cake Bakers.
Good wages and constant employment will be given to such as can come well recommended.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Timothy Kerse,
Port Mayo, below Rocketts. fe 26--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A Gardener, or a man used to farming; single or with a small family.--Apply to L S Squire, corner of Main and 1st streets, from 9 to 4 o'clock.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Immediately, a Professor of Music and a French Teacher.
None but those well qualified need apply.
Liberal salaries given.
Address "Box 180," Danville, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A man thoroughly acquainted with the Manufacture of Glass in all its branches can hear of something materially to his interest by addressing, immediately,

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Plain dark blue Silk Dresses or Remnants of Blue Silk or Scarlet.
The best prices paid.
div3.closer:
Miss Semon.
No. 36 Main street,
2 doors below St Charles Hos. fe 26--1t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A new Slutina, for which a liberal price will be given.
Any one having one to dispose of will leave it at this office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --By a young French lady, a situation in a small family to teach French For particulars, apply to
div3.closer:
F. Delarue,
Cor 6th and Broad sts. fe 26--eod3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By two young men in the employ of the Government, a furnished Room, east of 8th street and south of Broad.
Possession wanted 1st of March.
Address "J W," at this office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Fifty men for the "Provost Marshal's Guard' at Lynchburg.
Bounty $50 For particulars apply to
div3.closer:
H M Snovell,
Corner of 14th and Main sts. fe 28--1t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Gardener, for the balance of the year--one capable and well recommended.
Apply at this office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a lady a situation as Housekeeper in a private family, or as Pastry Cook in a hotel.
Address letter "M." at this office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --The Magistrates of Henrico county having impressed my only negro man to work on fortifications, I will pay a liberal price for an able bodied Hand to work in his place for 60 days. He is at work on batteries near Richmond.
div3.closer:
A J Torrell, M D,
On Brooke Road, 4½ miles from Richmond. fe 25--2t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a gentleman of some experience, and exempt from military service, a situation as Salesman or General Assistant in some commercial house, (auction or commission preferred.) Reliable city references given.
Address "L H," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--One or two Rooms, furnished or unfurnished, between 9th and 15th streets for which a liberal rent will be paid.
Address "G B," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --Flax Seed.--I will pay the highest cash price for Flax Seed in any quantity.

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--$100 reward.--Ran away from the subscriber, on the 18th inst, Annie Banions, taking with her some $220 in C S notes and $220 in gold.
She is in all probability lurking about the city and has been seen near the Medical College, and between that and Victor's Mid. The above reward will be paid for her delivery to me in Richmond with the money, or $50 for her alone.
Description: Bright mulatto, about five feet high and rather stout; aged 17 years; has bushy hair of a reddiah tinge, and large and good front teeth.

div3.head: Ran away.
div3.p:
--From the City Gas Works, on the 16th of February, 1863, four negro men-- Nat Boykin, Bob Harris, Jim Pollard and John Rose.
Nat is thick set, dark skin, and five feet four inches high.
Bob is stout, dark skin and five feet seven and a half inches high.
Jim is spare made, dark skin, and five feet seven inches high.
John is spare made, dark skin, and five feet seven inches high.
A liberal reward will be paid for the delivery of either or all of them at the City Gas Works.

div3.head: For Hire.
div3.p:
--A negro Woman, of good character, who is a good Washer and Ironer.
Apply to

div3.head: For Hire.
div3.p:
--A Girl, 16 years of age, who is an excellent House Servant and Nurse; also, a Woman, with two children, whom I would put out to a good home for their food and Clothes.
Inquire of
div3.closer:
T Taylor Engineers' Headq'rs,
Cor. 28th and Grace sts. fe 25--2t*

div3.head: Morris Artillery.
div3.p: --The following Members of my company now absent without leave are hereby notified that unless they report in person at this camp within seven days from date, they will be considered deserters and treated accordingly:
div3.closer:
William M Strong.
R C M Page,
Capt Com'g Morris Artillery,
D H Bill's Division.
Camp near Milford Depot, Feb. 22, 1863. fe 26--2t*

div3.head: Ninety Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Deserted from Co. C. 53d Va. Reg't--
Isaacking, complexion dark, hair dark, eyes blue, height 5 feet 7 inches, slight scar on the left cheek

George Ellis, age 46 years, complexion dark, hair dark and slightly gray, eyes blue, height 5 feet 4½ inches, bottom front teeth large and irregular, supposed to be lurking about Chesterfield Coal Pits.
The above reward will be paid for their delivery at Castle Thunder, or $45 for either.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Mallory Troop,
Richmond, February 20th, 1863.
div3.p:
A few more Recruits are wanted to fill up my company of Cavalry, to serve as Gen Lee's Body Guard.
Horses, equipment, a complete outfit, and $50 bounty, furnished to each recruit. --Those wishing to join this corps will report to me at Mr. Thos T Johnson's office opposite Columbian Hotel, or to Lieut David Johnson, at Camp Lee, by the 5th of March, as no recruits will be received after that time.

div3.head: Camp Lee, Feb. 20, 1863.
div3.p:
Deserted — From Camp Lee, on or about the 8th February, James Young a fisherman by trade, and substitute for D H White, Culpeper county.
Said Young is 47 years old, dark hair, dark eyes, dark complexion, and 5 feet 6 inches high.
A reward of $50 will be given for his delivery to Capt. Booker, at Castle Thunder

closer.signed: Lt com'dg co F, 21st Va Reg't.

div3.head: Camp Lee, Feb'y. 20, 1863.
div3.p:
Deserted — From Camp Lee on or about the 8th of February, H A Phillips, a farmer by trade.
Said H A Phillips is 37 years of age; blue eyes; dark hair; dark complexion, and 5 feet 10 ½ inches high.
A reward of $30 will be paid for his delivery to Capt Booker, at Castle Thunder.

closer.signed: Wm G Gray, Lt comd'g com'y F,

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p:
--From Camp Lee, on or about the 17th of February, John Coleman, a substitute, and an Irishman by birth Said John Coleman is 47 years of age, 5 feet 8 inches high, blue eyes dark hair, and dark complexion.
A reward of $30 will be paid for his delivery to Capt Booker, Castle Thunder.
div3.closer:
Wm G Gray,
Lieut Com'g Co F, 21st Va Reg't.
Camp Lee, Feb. 20, 1863. fe 21--eod3t*
